channel.title: Webb Telescope Features
channel.description: The latest NASA Features on the James Webb Space Telescope

item.title: Webb Telescope’s Houston Highlights
item.description: With NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope’s approximately nine-month stay in Texas coming to an end, now is a good time to reflect on the memories it made in the Lone Star State.

item.title: NASA Hosts Media to Discuss Testing on James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: Media are invited to NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston at 2 p.m. EST Wednesday, Jan. 10, to hear about the results of recent cryogenic vacuum tests on the James Webb Space Telescope, and the next steps on the observatory's path to space.

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope to Investigate Mysterious Brown Dwarfs
item.description: Astronomers are hopeful that the powerful infrared capability of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope will resolve a puzzle as fundamental as stargazing itself — what IS that dim light in the sky?

item.title: Webb Telescope’s “Silver and Gold Decorations”
item.description: You won’t catch NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope saying “Bah, humbug!” to seasonal festivities.

item.title: How Hardy Is Webb? A Q&A About the Toughness of NASA’s Webb Telescope
item.description: Just how resilient does a space telescope have to be to survive both Earth’s environment and the frigid, airless environment of space?

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope Emerges from Chamber A
item.description: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope, or Webb, emerged from Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston on Dec. 1 to prepare for its upcoming move to California.

item.title: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope Completes Final Cryogenic Testing
item.description: The vault-like, 40-foot diameter, 40-ton door of Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston was unsealed on November 18, signaling the end of cryogenic testing for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope.

item.title: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Early Science Observations Revealed
item.description: Astronomers around the world will have immediate access to early data from specific science observations from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope, which will be completed within the first five months of Webb’s science operations.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope’s Laser-Focused Sight
item.description: About 1 million miles away from the nearest eye surgeon, NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope will be able to perfect its own vision while in orbit.

item.title: Self-Portrait of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope Marks Critical Test
item.description: What appears to be a unique selfie opportunity was actually a critical photo for the cryogenic testing of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope in Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston.

item.title: What Lurks Below NASA’s Chamber A?
item.description: Hidden beneath Chamber A at the Johnson Space Center is an area engineers used to test critical contamination control technology that has helped keep our James Webb Space Telescope clean during cryogenic testing.

item.title: What Lurks Below NASA’s Chamber A?
item.description: Hidden beneath Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston is an area engineers used to test critical contamination control technology that has helped keep NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope clean during cryogenic testing.

item.title: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope and the Big Bang: A Short Q&A with Nobel Laureate Dr. John Mather
item.description: In this Q&A, Dr. John Mather, a Nobel laureate and the senior project scientist for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope, answers some commonly asked questions about this expanding universe story, and about Webb’s role in understanding the early history of the universe.

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope to Witness Galactic Infancy
item.description: Scientists will use NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope to study sections of the sky previously observed by NASA’s Great Observatories, including the Hubble Space Telescope and the Spitzer Space Telescope, to understand the creation of the universe’s first galaxies and stars.

item.title: Hubble Is Paving Scientific Paths for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope is helping identify potential celestial targets for the James Webb Space Telescope through a series of preparatory science observations to be completed before Webb is ready to make observations of its own.

item.title: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope to be Launched Spring 2019
item.description: The launch date was moved after the team reassessed the schedule following testing.

item.title: Engineers Warm NASA’s Webb Telescope as End of Cryogenic Testing Nears
item.description: The temperature of Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston has begun to rise, signaling the beginning of the end of James Webb Space Telescope’s cryogenic testing.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope Team Members Volunteer Following Historic Texas Hurricane
item.description: Several members of the James Webb Space Telescope team stationed at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston volunteered over the Labor Day weekend to help clean up and repair damage to the city caused by Hurricane Harvey.

item.title: Aligning the Primary Mirror Segments of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope with Light
item.description: Engineers at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston used light waves to align the James Webb Space Telescope’s mirror segments to each other, so they act like a single, monolithic mirror in the cryogenic cold of the center’s iconic Chamber A.

item.title: Keeping NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope in the Dark
item.description: Technicians working on JWST ensure no unwanted infrared light interferes with the optical testing of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope inside of Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston.

item.title: NASA Awards New Cooperative Agreement to W. M. Keck Observatory
item.description: NASA has awarded a five-year Cooperative Agreement with the California Association for Research in Astronomy to continue the science program at the W. M. Keck Observatory.

item.title: Astronomers Around World Submit Science Proposals for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: NASA's call for proposals for the James Webb telescope garnered 106 proposals from 38 countries.

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope Will Study Our Solar System’s “Ocean Worlds”
item.description: Webb telescope’s observations might be particularly telling for the plumes on Europa, the composition of which largely remains a mystery.

item.title: How Does NASA’s Webb Telescope Stay Cool in Chamber A?
item.description: Objects in a vacuum, like the Webb telescope inside of Chamber A, primarily cool through a heat-transfer process called radiation. For an object to radiatively cool, it must be in view of another, colder object.

item.title: NASA's Webb Telescope Summertime Deep-Freeze Continues
item.description: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope began a nearly 100-day cryogenic test in a giant chamber in Texas in mid-July.

item.title: Sunshield Layers Fully Integrated on NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: The five sunshield layers responsible for protecting the optics and instruments of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope are now fully installed.

item.title: NASA Tests the Webb Telescope’s Communication Skills
item.description: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope recently completed its Ground Segment Test Number 1 (GSEG-1), for the first time confirming successful end-to-end communication between the telescope and its mission operations center.

item.title: NASA’s Webbcam Shows Webb Telescope Chilling in Chamber A
item.description: The temperature of Chamber A at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston is steadily dropping, creating a frigid environment for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope that is in stark contrast to the heat of the city.

item.title: NASA Closes Chamber A Door to Commence Webb Telescope Testing
item.description: The vault-like, 40-ton door of Johnson Space Center's historic Chamber A sealed shut on July 11, 2017, signaling the beginning of about three months of cryogenic testing for NASA's James Webb Space Telescope in Houston.

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope ‘Hangs Out’ in Houston
item.description: In preparation for James Webb Space Telescope's upcoming cryogenic testing, engineers at NASA's Johnson Space Center have suspended the telescope from the ceiling of the center's historic Chamber A.

item.title: NASA Astrophysicist to Discuss the Search for Earth-like Exoplanets at Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum
item.description: NASA Astrophysicist Amber Straughn will give a talk about the search for Earth-like exoplanets to launch the 2017 season of Family Astronomy nights at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum on Friday, July 14.

item.title: NASA's Webb Telescope Gets Freezing Summertime Lodging in Houston
item.description: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope was placed in Johnson Space Center’s historic Chamber A on June 20, 2017, to prepare for its final three months of testing in a cryogenic vacuum that mimics temperatures in space.

item.title: Webb Telescope Set for Testing in Space Simulation Chamber
item.description: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope sits in front of the door to Chamber A, a giant thermal vacuum chamber located at NASA’s Johnson Space Center. The telescope will soon be moved into the chamber, where it will spend a hot Houston summer undergoing tests at sub-freezing cryogenic temperatures.

item.title: NASA 2017 OPSPARC Winners Put a New Spin on Webb Telescope Technology
item.description: NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, announced the winners of the 2017 OPTIMUS PRIME Spinoff Promotion and Research Challenge (OPSPARC) on May 5, 2017.

item.title: Icy Moons, Galaxy Clusters, and Distant Worlds Among Selected Targets for James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: Mission officials for NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope announced some of the science targets the telescope will observe following its launch and commissioning.

item.title: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope says “Open Wide” to Chamber A
item.description: NASA's Johnson Space Center’s "Chamber A" in Houston is an enormous thermal vacuum testing chamber and now appears to be opening it's "mouth" to take in NASA's James Webb Space Telescope for testing.

item.title: NASA's Apollo-Era Test Chamber Now James Webb Space Telescope Ready
item.description: The telescope was transported from NASA Goddard to NASA Johnson on May 4, 2017. After several weeks of unpacking, deploying, and instrumenting for the test, the chamber door will be closed and the flight hardware will be tested around-the-clock for 93 straight days.

item.title: NASA's "Webb-cam" Captures Engineers at Work on Webb at Johnson Space Center
item.description: At Johnson Space Center a special Webb camera was installed there to continue providing daily video feeds on the telescope's progress.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope Available for Media Viewing at NASA’s Johnson Space Center
item.description: Media are invited to NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston to view the James Webb Space Telescope and talk to experts about upcoming cryogenic vacuum tests at 10:15 a.m. CDT Wednesday, May 31.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope Primary Mirror Prepared for Testing at Johnson Space Center
item.description: The towering primary mirror of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope stands inside a cleanroom at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston, where it will undergo its last cryogenic test before it is launched into space in 2018. In preparation for testing, the “wings” of the mirror (which consist of the three segments on each side) were spread open.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope Arrives at NASA’s Johnson Space Center
item.description: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has arrived at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas.

item.title: NASA’s Webb Telescope Completes Goddard Testing, Heading to Texas for More
item.description: After undergoing rigorous environmental tests simulating the stresses of its rocket launch, the Webb telescope team at Goddard analyzed the results from this critical optical test and compared it to the pre-test measurements.

item.title: James Webb Space Telescope Mirror Seen in Full Bloom
item.description: It's springtime and the deployed primary mirror of NASA's James Webb Space Telescope looks like a spring flower in full bloom. Once launched into space, the Webb telescope’s 18-segmented gold mirror is specially designed to capture infrared light from the first galaxies that formed in the early universe.

item.title: Planet Hunters Named in TIME’s Top 100 Most Influential People
item.description: Three extraordinary planet-hunters have been recognized by TIME Magazine as this year’s top 100 most influential people: Natalie Batalha from NASA’s Ames Research Center in California’s Silicon Valley; Michael Gillon from the University of Liège in Belgium; and Guillem Anglada-Escudé from the Queen Mary University in London.

item.title: An Inside Look at NASA's Webb Telescope Art Exhibit
item.description: Twenty-five applicants were selected to visit in November 2016, and peered into Goddard's giant cleanroom where the telescope was being tested. The results of that visit are now on display at the NASA Goddard Visitor Center.

item.title: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Completes Acoustic and Vibration Tests
item.description: At NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland the James Webb Space Telescope team completed the acoustic and vibration portions of environmental testing on the telescope.

item.title: NASA's Webb Telescope Ghostly 'Lights Out' Inspection
item.description: The technicians who are inspecting the telescope and its expansive golden mirrors look like ghostly wraiths in this image as they conduct a "lights out inspection" in the Spacecraft Systems Development and Integration Facility (SSDIF) at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.

item.title: Media, Public Invited to Visit NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Exhibit at 'South by Southwest'
item.description: NASA is partnering with the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) and the Northrop Grumman Corporation to highlight the James Webb Space Telescope at South by Southwest (SXSW) from March 12 to 18, 2017.

item.title: Probing Seven Worlds with NASA's James Webb Space Telescope
item.description: With the discovery of seven earth-sized planets around the TRAPPIST-1 star 40 light years away, astronomers are looking to the upcoming James Webb Space Telescope to help us find out if any of these planets could possibly support life.

item.title: NASA's Webb Telescope Team Prepares For Earsplitting Acoustic Test
item.description: Inside NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland the James Webb Space Telescope team completed the environmental portion of vibration testing and prepared for the acoustic test on the telescope.
